title: Meningitis
description: Mentions key items in suspected bacterial meningitis and meningococcal sepsis.

title: Encephalitis
description: Suspect encephalitis whenever odd behavior, reduced consciousness, focal neurology, or seizures occur after an infectious prodrome (fever, rash, lymphadenopathy, cold sores, conjunctivitis, or meningeal signs).

title: Cerebral abscess
description: Suspect this in any patient with increased ICP, especially if there is fever or increased TLC. It may follow ear, sinus, dental, or periodontal infection; skull fracture; congenital heart disease; endocarditis; bronchiectasis. It may also occur in the absence of systemic signs of inflammation.

title: Status Epilepticus
description: Seizures lasting for more than 30 minutes or repeated seizures without regaining consciousness between them.

title: Head Injury
description: Mentions key items in head injury management.

title: Raised intracranial pressure (ICP)
description: The volume inside the cranium is ﬁxed, so any increase in the contents can lead to raised ICP. This can be mass effect, edema, or obstruction to ﬂuid outﬂow. Normal ICP in adults is <15mmHg.
